Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Successive Wildfire Influence on Forested Depressional Wetlands in Southern Florida
Award.AbstractNarration:
A wildfire in the wetland-mosaic landscape of Big Cypress National Preserve, Florida, offers a sudden and time-critical opportunity to understand what happens to forested wetlands when drought and fire occur in quick succession. In this instance, an area that experienced wildfire during severe drought in 2009 burned again only four years later (March 2013) and also during regional drought conditions. A series of studies after the 2009 wildfire provide considerable pre-2013 fire data, making this opportunity highly unusual from the standpoint of fires in wetlands. By making measurements of fire severity, tree mortality and loss of soil, this project will provide critical information on the resilience of wetlands to fire and drought.

Cypress domes store water long into the region's annual dry season. They thus provide important habitat for wildlife; refugia that concentrate prey organisms; and a distributed network of recharge basins for the shallow aquifer that supplies southwestern Florida's growing human population. The combination of projected climate change and human-altered hydrology is likely to result in more frequent and severe wildfires. By understanding the combined effects of drought and repeated wildfires on these wetland-mosaic landscapes, the project is expected to inform fire management strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Because of its abundant rainfall, well-known humidity, and wealth of wetland ecosystems, Florida is not considered by much of the public to be a significant area of wildfire activity. Quite to the contrary, however, the Sunshine state also has been called “the land of fire and water.” Well-drained, sandy soils, and seasonal distribution of rainfall that result in a “dry season” in large parts of the state, mean that lightning arriving with thunderstorms ignite many wildfires throughout the year. Ecosystems in Florida have adapted to the presence of frequent fire, aided by the rainfall that allows them to regrow rapidly—thus producing more fuel for future fires. The same is true for many wetlands that experience periodic drydowns, making them vulnerable for wildfires too.

Opportunities to observe the effects of multiple, successive fires are therefore common for upland ecosystems in Florida (such as pine flatwoods and savannas), but they are rare for wetlands due to the low likelihood that a combination of drought and wildfire will occur within only a few years after a previous fire—especially in an area where researchers have the chance to study the effects of both fires. However, in 2013, this opportunity materialized when the Huckabee Fire burned across much of the same area that had been burned in the 2009 Deep Fire. Just as in 2009, the dry period that precedes the start of the rainy season had been particularly dry, allowing the fire to burn into desiccated wetlands—the same wetlands that had been burned in 2009 (see images).

This study was designed to investigate whether effects of this second fire differed significantly from the ones observed in the 2009 fire. Investigators measured fire severity, tree mortality, soil consumption, and canopy recovery, as well as a number of other variables. One of the findings was that fire severity was much lower in this second fire. Also, fire-caused mortality of the pondcypress trees that characterize the small, geographically isolated wetlands (called “domes” because from afar they appear to have a dome-shaped canopy, caused by shorter trees at their edges than at their centers) was lower.

These primary findings are likely explained by lower amounts of fuel available for consumption during the 2013 fire, since accumulation of fuel was low after four years compared with those in 2009, prior to which the wetlands had not been visited by fire for several years. Also, individual trees affected by the 2009 fire had had four years to recover from damage, and those most susceptible to fire-caused mortality may have already been killed in 2009.

A number of additional findings were produced by this study, one of which concerns the effects that fire has on the microclimate within cypress domes. Another outcome from the study has been the development of scientific models to explore the effects of fire on the hydrology of landscapes containing ecosystems such as these cypress domes, where soils can contain such high percentages of carbon that fires during very dry periods can ignite them, effectively making them deeper in some areas. These outcomes have been published as journal articles, and presented at a number of professional talks as well as seminars for the public and workshops for local managers. Finally, the support provided by NSF for this study also has provided summer employment and training opportunities for a handful of undergraduate students in the areas of fire ecology, at least one of whom reported that the experience helped influence her decision to pursue graduate school
